Dear Christy Shillings:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately please contact the area manager, Rorie Dodge-Pifer at (517) 899-6024.

III. INVESTIGATION
1

Rule Code Sufficiency of staff.
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126
Section (1) The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
Description supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty to
perform the prescribed functions required by these administrative
rules and in the agency’s program statement and to provide for the
continual needs, protection, and supervision of residents
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 6/23/24, youth was hiding in a cubicle from other youth that
were trying to assault him. Staff sprayed youth with a fire
extinguisher to get the youth to leave the cubicle. The youth's skin
was burning, and he had to vomit as a result. Youth went outside
to vomit and staff would not let the youth return so youth left and
returned 30 minutes later. Staff still refused to allow youth back
into the facility. Youth slept at a gas station and attempted to
return the next day, but staff would not allow it. Youth went to the
police station and was brought back to the facility by law
enforcement on 6/24/24. Staff threatened to have another youth
assault this youth. Youth went AWOL again and was transported
back by law enforcement on 6/25/24. Staff would not let the youth
back into the facility, so youth went to the police department.
Investigation Interviews:
On 06/26/2024 an email was sent to Foster Care Worker (FCW)
advising of allegations involving Youth A.
On 06/26/2024 a voicemail message was left for Complainant
requesting a return call if there were any additional concerns.
On 06/26/2024 a telephone call was held with DHHS Specialist.
She advised of conversation with Complainant. She stated the
complainant confirmed the allegations as accurately reported.
She recalled that Youth A did appear to have some discoloration
to his arm but was unsure if it was from the child being outside or
being sprayed. She also advised that Complainant stated that
Youth A seemed like he was afraid to return to Wolverine due to
being threatened by some staff.
On 06/26/2024 a joint interview of Youth A was completed along
with DHHS Specialist 2 via telephone. Youth A and DHHS
Specialist 2 were located at the Clinton County DHHS office in St.
2

Johns, MI. Youth A advised that he was arguing with Staff 1 and
Staff 2 at Wolverine a few days ago. He stated he ran into the
cubicle because he was being chased by six residents that were
mad with him because he was fighting with Staff 2. He stated the
office is normally unlocked and stated on this day the medical cart
was also unlocked but denied that he touched anything. He
reported that Staff 1 came into the office and told him to come out
or she was going to spray him with the fire extinguisher. About 5
to 10 seconds later he reported that she sprayed the extinguisher
at the wall over his head. He stated he then grabbed an
extinguisher that happened to be in the cubicle and sprayed it
back but aimed it into the air and accidentally sprayed himself. He
then reported he was sprayed directly in the face with the
extinguisher by Staff 1. He was adamant that he did not spray
first. He also advised that there are no cameras in the office area.
Youth A reported he then ran outside because he was choking,
and his skin was burning from the fire extinguisher. He threw up
and then tried to reenter the building, but Staff 1 and Staff 2
refused to let him back in and said they were never going to let
him back in again. He reported he left Wolverine, went to the gas
station on Jefferson and pumped gas for money and then took the
bus to Belle Isle. He reported he hung out there and went
swimming in the river and around 9 or 10 pm that same day he
walked back to Wolverine (which he said took him two hours) and
knocked on the door, but no one answered. He reported he then
walked to the Citgo and stayed there until morning. The gas
station closed at 2 or 3 am and he just sat outside until daytime.
In the morning, he reported he walked to the 5th precinct and told
an officer what had happened, but the officer made him mad and
he left and went back to the Citgo gas station and stayed there
until the next day. He reported that he again returned to
Wolverine and they allowed him back into the facility. He recalled
that he remained for the day, but when he went outside later that
day for about 30 minutes, they refused to let him back in. Youth A
denied that there were any other youth outside at the time. He
reported Staff 1 and Staff 2 then threatened to have a resident
“whoop his ass” so he took off again and went back to the Citgo
gas station. While he was at the gas station, he reported that an
unknown man and woman asked if he was ok or needed a ride
and drove him to the 10th precinct. An officer from the precinct
drove him back to Wolverine but was told that he was no longer a
client at the facility. The police took him back to the station and
contacted DHHS. Youth A stated he purchased food while he was
AWOL from money he earned while pumping gas for people at the
gas station. He denied that he went to anyone’s home in the
3

community while he was AWOL. He then reported he was sleepy
and asked to end the interview.
The following interviews took place at Wolverine Center along
with DHHS Specialist on 06/27/2024 unless otherwise noted.
Interview of Chief Administrator was completed. She was
advised of allegations. She provided copies of the incident reports
involving Youth A from the facility. The Chief Administrator
advised that the allegations were incorrect. She recalled that
Youth A actually sprayed the staff with the extinguisher, and it
occurred on 6/22/2024 and not on 06/22/2023. She confirmed
that the incident occurred in the office space and that there are no
cameras in that area. Chief Administrator reports Youth A was
gone for over 24 hours before she closed his bed. He was gone
from 10 am on 6/24 to 3:30 pm on 6/25. She advised that the
policy allows for closure of the bed of youth in the shelter program
if they are AWOL for more than 24 hours. She stated at no point
did staff refuse to allow Youth A back into the facility if he had
been gone for less than 24 hours or had been seen within the 24-
hour time frame. She also confirmed that when youth return to the
facility from AWOL status they are allowed to enter the building,
but are housed in the atrium or conference room area in the very
front of the building. Youth are searched in this area and
assessed for the need of medical treatment. The Chief
Administrator further advised that once youth are cleared (no
issues with search or need for medical treatment) they are then
escorted beyond this point into the residential area.
After interviewing all staff and youth at the facility, an additional
interview was completed with Chief Administrator. The safety plan
was implemented and reviewed with Chief Administrator by DHHS
Specialist. The Chief Administrator also advised us that while we
had been interviewing other youth and staff, Youth A had come to
the facility with an adult male who was threatening staff to allow
Youth A back into the facility. She reported law enforcement was
contacted and the FCW updated. Youth A left with the unknown
male and walked up the street out of the sight of Wolverine staff.
Chief Administrator confirmed that when Foster Care staff came to
pick up medication of Youth A from the facility, he went AWOL out
the back seat of the vehicle.
On 09/19/2024 an interview was completed with the Chief
Administrator. She confirmed that the practice of having every
youth seen by the medical after returning from AWOL is “best
practice” and not “policy”. She further reiterated that youth are
4

allowed back into the building and are searched and assessed in
the atrium/conference room in the front of the building. Once
cleared, they are they escorted to the residential area.
Interview of Staff 1 was completed. Staff 1 reported that Youth A
was in the building while other youth went out for an outing. Youth
A was unable to go because of his behavior. It was around noon
when she and two other staff (Staff 2 and Staff 3) were in the
office with Youth A. She recalled that Youth A did not have
breakfast yet, so she with permission from Chief Administrator
ordered a special breakfast as a motivator for Youth A. Staff 1
reported that they chose to eat in the main office with Youth A and
did not believe it would be an issue since he was staffed 3 to 1.
Youth A requested to make a call to his sister, he was told no and
became escalated in his behavior. He grabbed one of the fire
extinguishers that were in the office (from being torn off the walls
by the residents) and began to spray it. She recalled that all of the
staff present assisted and were able to get the extinguisher from
him, but she and Staff 2 had to restrain him for about 20 seconds
until he was able to calm down. Once out of the restraint he ran
out the front door. Staff 2 and Staff 3 followed and made attempts
to get him to return. Staff 1 denied that she or any of the other
staff attempted to spray Youth A. She also denied that any
threats were made to harm Youth A or have any other youth harm
him. She further denied knowledge of any staff refusing him
access if he attempted to return to the facility. Staff 1 reported
that Youth A frequently goes AWOL and does not like to follow
protocol when he returns to ensure his safety and the safety of
other youth in the program. Staff 1 reported she was advised by
the Chief Administrator on 6/25/2024 that the bed of Youth A had
been closed since he was gone for over 24 hours. She did recall
that he came back to the agency after this date and she advised
him that his bed was closed and assisted him in making a call to
Law Enforcement and his FCW, however Youth A quickly took off
again in a random car. Staff 1 denied that Youth A had access to
any medication and advised he was only able to access an
extinguisher in the office because he and other youth had ripped
them from the wall. The extinguishers were being stored in the
office for replacement and reinstalment.
Interview of Staff 2 was completed. Staff 2 reported she was
eating breakfast in the main office with Youth A, Staff 1 and Staff
3. Youth A was the only youth in the building because others
were on an outing and Youth A was not able to go based on his
behavior. She recalled that at one point Youth A asked to call his
sister and when told no, he became upset. He ran into the mail
5

room of the main office, grabbed the fire extinguisher and began
to spray it. The extinguishers were in the office because youth
had been ripping them off the walls. He began to spray the
extinguisher at the staff and they attempted to redirect him. Staff
2 recalled that she and Staff 1 had to restrain Youth A and it
lasted for about 20 seconds. Once released from the restraint,
Youth A ran out the door. Staff 2 reported that Staff 3 followed
him outside while the other staff completed the necessary reports
and started to clean the office. Staff 2 denied that any threats
were made toward Youth A and denied that any staff sprayed him
with the extinguisher. She also denied that Youth A was denied
entry into the facility if he attempted to return. She did report that
he does not want to follow the protocol and frequently goes AWOL
from the facility. She denied that Youth A ever had access to an
open medication cart in the office.
Interview of Youth B was completed. He reported that both Staff
1 and Staff 2 are the best staff at Wolverine and denied having
any concerns with them. He denied hearing either of them ever
speak inappropriately to any youth, especially Youth A. He denied
knowledge of staff making threats toward Youth A or attempting to
physically hurt him. Youth B denied having any knowledge
regarding the spraying of the fire extinguisher but confirmed that
Youth A was the only youth that did not go on the outing that
morning. Youth B denied ever being approached by staff about
fighting with another youth and stated the staff are better than
that. Youth B requested to end the interview.
Interview of Youth C was completed. Youth C reported feeling
very safe with Staff 1 and Staff 2. He denied ever hearing the
staff make threats regarding youth. Youth C confirmed that Youth
A was required to remain at the facility while all other youth went
on an outing. Youth C stated that Youth A does not listen to staff
and always goes AWOL.
On 7/19/2024 a DHHS Disposition hearing was held. DCWL staff
was unable to participate in the conference due to absence from
the office. DHHS Specialist advised of no findings as a result of
the investigation.
Documents Reviewed:
Social Work Contact: On 07/29/2024 Social Work Contact
(SWC) dated 7/15/2024 written by DHHS Specialist was reviewed.
DHHS specialist completed a telephone interview with Staff 3. I
was unable to participate due to a previously scheduled
conference for another case. Staff 3 recalled the incident in the
6

office involving the fire extinguisher. She was Youth A’s one-to-
one staff for the morning shift of 6/22/23 and he had been
demonstrating excessive behaviors all morning. He was upset
because he was unable to go on the scheduled outing. All of the
other youth were gone on the outing and Youth A remained
behind. Staff 3 reported Youth A was able to de-escalate and was
brought into the main office area to color, listen to music and eat.
He expressed a desire to talk to his therapist, but the therapist
was too busy and Youth A was told to wait. Youth A wanted his
therapist to call his sister. It frustrated Youth A when the therapist
was not able to call his sister and was told he had to wait. She
reported he began to act out again. Youth A grabbed one of the
fire extinguishers that were in the office from being ripped off the
wall by other residents. He then proceeded to spray toward Staff
1 and Staff 2. She denied that the staff ever sprayed or
threatened to spray Youth A. Staff 3 stated that Youth A required
a restraint to stop him and when he was released he eventually
ran out of the facility. Staff 3 went outside in an attempt to
continue efforts to de-escalate Youth A. Youth A ended up
urinating in a bottle and attempting to throw it on her. When she
went into the building, he threw the urine at the door. She
reported she walked back outside and attempted to de-escalate
him but he ran off and went AWOL. The SWC also documented
that he returned about three or four hours later with some
unknown men from the community making threats to the agency
staff. Staff 3 said she was successful in getting Youth A to come
to stay at the facility, but he eventually left again. She reported
there were occasions that Youth A attempted to return from
AWOL status and did not want to wait or follow the proper protocol
for a medical clearance before coming back into the facility. She
denied knowledge of any time that Youth A, or any youth, has
been denied access to the facility unless they were no longer
residents. Staff 3 denied ever hearing any threats from staff
regarding Youth A and denied that Youth A had access to an open
medication cart at any point.
On 09/19/2024 a telephone interview was completed with Staff 3.
She reported that staff make attempts to deter youth from going
AWOL. She confirmed that when youth return from AWOL they
are allowed to enter the building and are searched and assessed
in the front corridor. All youth are offered a medical exam, if they
decline it is documented on the refusal form and
Wolverine AWOL Policy: Staff will make efforts to verbally
redirect the truanting youth and will offer the youth support and
alternatives to truancy. If a non-supervising staff is available, they
7

will walk with the youth and continue to provide verbal support and
redirection encouraging the youth not to truant.
Staff will immediately notify the Youth Care Specialist Supervisor
on duty when line of sight is lost, no later than 15 minutes from
loss of line of sight (when youth is determined AWOL). The Youth
Specialist Supervisor will contact the Lead Supervisor and
Program Management who will provide oversight for incident
management. The youth specialist supervisor will ensure law
enforcement is notified immediately (no more than 5 minutes from
when youth is determined AWOL.) Staff will notify law
enforcement and program director. Client specifics will be
provided to Law enforcement and an IR will be completed.
When a Client Returns:
If the client returns to the site, the appropriate supervising agency
must be contacted for authorization to re-admit the client and
remove the client’s truancy status. 1. NOTE: If a shelter client, the
Placement Unit must be notified and must provide authorization to
re-admit the client. 2. All other parties notified of truancy must
also be notified at the time of return.
Youth A Incident Reports:
Incident Report 6/22 at 12:07pm documented that Youth A
became upset and high speed after talking to clinical staff to see if
he could contact his sister. Youth A ran in the back of the main
office in the mail room and grabbed a fire extinguisher and began
spraying towards staff. Staff were able to secure the extinguisher
from him, but Youth A then ran to grab another one. He was
placed in a high standing restraint. Once client was released, he
ran out the front door.
Incident Report 6/23 at 9pm documented Youth A was a very high
speed while waiting to get medical clearance, staff was waiting for
driver. While waiting, Youth A began to walk towards Dickerson
through a neighbor's backyard, staff lost sight of Youth A. Staff
redirected client multiple times to stay in the building to get
medical clearance, but youth continued to walk away and refused.
Incident Report 6/23 10pm documented staff attempted to redirect
Youth A near the administrative area to have a seat, but he
became verbally abusive towards staff and attempted to physically
assault staff as well. Youth A was attempted to be redirected
multiple times.
8

Incident Report 6/24 at 10:20am documented Youth A was
arguing with another client, he asked if he could take a walk
around the corner, but staff stated he was not allowed. Youth A
stated "well I want to go swimming at Belle Isle" and started to
walk anyways up Lenox and toward Jefferson. Staff contacted
supervision and advised where Youth A was walking as staff
followed behind him. Staff lost sight at 10:30am and returned to
the building after notifying supervision.
Timeline of AWOL Status of Youth A: Copy of a written timeline
identifying AWOL of Youth A was provided. It indicated the
following:
6/22
• 1pm AWOL
• 4pm Seen by staff and clients during an outing at Belle Isle
and refused to get in the car with staff
• 11pm Arrived to facility by getting dropped off by group of
people.
6/23
• 6:20pm returned to facility with group of angry people in
car.
• 9:20pm AWOL
• 10:30pm Returned to facility, physically aggressive with
staff. Finally went to hospital for medical clearance, but he
refused to be seen once there
6/24
• 12:36pm Youth went AWOL immediately upon return from
hospital.
• 6:25am Law enforcement returned client to facility
• 10:20am Youth went AWOL again
6/25
• 1:25p Bed of Youth A closed
Analysis The agency is found in compliance with the licensing rule. At the
conclusion of the investigation there was no evidence to support
that the staff had sprayed the youth with the extinguishers,
refused to let the youth back into the facility or threatened to have
a youth assault Youth A. Interviews of Youth A were inconsistent
and unable to establish any consistency regarding the allegations.
Interviews of other youth and staff supported that Youth A would
frequently AWOL from the facility and initiate conflict with other
youth.
9

Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Program statement
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following: (c)
Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care, safety, and
supervision, methods for addressing residents’ needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Agency failed to create and enforce policy relative to youth not
being in the administrative area.
Investigation On 06/26/2024 a joint interview of Youth A was completed along
with DHHS Specialist 2 via telephone. Youth A and DHHS
Specialist 2 were located at the Clinton County DHHS office in St.
Johns, MI. Youth A reported that on 6/23/2024 he ran into an
office at Wolverine Human Services that was unlocked and hid in
the cubicle area. He stated he ran into the cubicle because he
was being chased by six residents that were mad with him
because he was fighting with Staff 2.
The following interviews took place at Wolverine Center along
with DHHS Specialist on 06/27/2024 unless otherwise noted.
Interview of Chief Administrator was completed. She could not
recall how Youth A got into the office space but stated that there is
no policy that states youth are not allowed in the admin space.
She stated there is a sign posted that says no youth allowed in the
area, but it was added by staff and not administration.
Interview of Staff 1 was completed. She denied that there is any
policy about youth being in the office, but it is best practice that
they are not allowed.
Tour:
A tour of the area where the incident occurred was completed on
6/27/2024 along with DHHS Specialist. The area was the
administrative office area and signage was observed that
indicated no clients were allowed in the area. Fire extinguishers,
10

medical cart, office supplies and other administrative objects were
observed in the area.
Documents Reviewed:
Wolverine Human Services Posted Signage that documents that
youth are not allowed in the main office area.
Analysis The agency was found to be in non-compliance with the licensing
rule. The Chief Administrator confirmed that the agency does not
have an official policy relative to youth not being in the
administrative area. However, staff are advised of this protocol
and there is signage on display in the area prohibiting youth from
being in the area.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established

Based on investigative findings the facility is in non-compliance with all applicable
